Background Lead-acid battery (LAB) manufacturing is growing in Bangladesh because of the expanding automotive industry and low lead prices. Although these factories employ a big workforce, the working environment has led to concerns about the possible health risks for employees. This study aimed to address this issue by investigating workplace chemical and physical hazards in three LAB industries and evaluating health outcomes among workers. Methods A cross-sectional study was conducted among 72 LAB factory workers, and participants were recruited by simple random sampling. A validated questionnaire was used to collect information on self-reported exposures to physical and chemical risks and related health effects. Data analysis was performed by using statistical software SPSS version 25. Results The age and work experience (Mean ± SD) of the participants were 34.2 ± 7.7 and 10.0 ± 5.7 years, respectively. High workplace temperature and noise from machinery, chemical odors, and skin exposure to acid (H 2 4 Conclusion Our study findings indicate that workers in LAB factories in Bangladesh are exposed to extreme temperatures, hazardous materials, and uncomfortable levels of noise, which can lead to serious health risks. To ensure the safety and well-being of employees, the LAB manufacturing sector in Bangladesh requires the immediate implementation of proper occupational health and safety standards. Lead-acid battery (LAB) factories are a growing sector in Bangladesh. Many local and foreign investors are keeping a role in LAB production in Bangladesh. Nowadays acid batteries are used in various sectors for our daily necessities like, solar plants, automobile cars, easy bikes, auto-rickshaws, uninterruptible power sources, etc. Bangladesh has many factories that focus on exports of LAB products. Most of the major LAB companies in Bangladesh both produce and export LABs for domestic and foreign markets [ 3 3 Pure Earth’s investigators have identified eighty-five (85) sites in Bangladesh that were categorized as pollution sources (LAB recycling, manufacturing, repair, etc.) from February 2016 to January 2018 [ 4 5 6 7 7 7 8 9 10 11 12 13 14 2 Materials and methodology 2.1 Study design and area A cross-sectional study design was carried out to evaluate the effects of work patterns and the impact of workplace environment on the health of LAB-producing factory workers. This study was conducted in Gazipur district of Bangladesh. The geographical location of the study area was situated within a one-kilometer radius around latitude 23.99 and longitude 90.25. Gazipur district is well-known as an industrial zone to produces a wide range of goods. These production areas play a significant role in Bangladesh's economy and support exports to other countries. The research was conducted in September and October of 2019. The top four LAB factories of Gazipur district have been chosen for this investigation. The range of the workforce of these factories was 300–600. 2.2 Ethical approval The experimental design and protocol were reviewed and approved by the Ethical Committee of Sylhet Agricultural University, Sylhet 3100, Bangladesh. 2.3 Participant’s selection Selecting participants was done by simple random sampling method. In the Gazipur district there were twenty-one LAB-producing factories where near about N = 1500 workers are directly or indirectly engaged in LAB production. The sample size has been calculated by a formula [Sample Size = Z 2 . P ( 1 − p ) e 2 1 + Z 2 . P ( 1 − p ) e 2 N 2.4 Study tools and data collection For the data collection tools, a well-organized structured questionnaire has been used. During the data collection, a face-to-face interview was performed. A combination of open-end (thirty-five questions) and close-end (six questions) questions were used in the questionnaire. A total of forty-one questions were used in the questionnaire. The forty-one questions have been divided into four sections (Sections A-D) where Section A included basic information about the participants. Section B involved in participants’ work patterns. Section C incorporated on participants’ workplace environment. Section D takes into regarding the health outcomes of the workers. All questions in the Section D were regarding the most common lead exposure symptoms. In Section C, six environment-related questions (like presence or absence of discomfort temperature, humidity, smoke, sound, dust, and chemical smell) are answered by the participants themselves. Prior to the interview, the field research assistant took the written consent from the participants and mentioned objectives of this research to participants. All the data were collected from inside the factory while the participants were working. Every interview lasted roughly fifteen minutes. No clinical information and biological samples were collected for this study. Within sixty days, seven field trips were used to gather all the data. To guarantee the quality of the data, field research assistants received expert training in data collection, data entry, record keeping, interviewing, and motivational speech. The questionnaire was translated into Bengali before taking the interview. 2.5 Analysis of data For the statistical analysis, IBM SPSS version 25 was used. Frequency and percentage were used to interpret the categorical variables. The mean (M) and standard deviation were used to interpret the continuous variables (SD). All the analyses were calculated in two steps. In the first step, we calculated the frequency and percentile of the variables. Then we sorted out the top nine frequencies of work patterns and workplace environments that were harmful to the participants. LBP: Low Back Pain. § ESP: Eyesight Problem. || HBP: High Blood Pressure. 4 Discussion The present study aimed to assess the occupational hazards faced by workers in LAB factories in Bangladesh, focusing on excess heat, noise, chemical exposures, and their potential health impacts. The findings from this research shed light on the alarming conditions prevailing in these factories, emphasizing the urgent need for interventions to safeguard the health and well-being of the workers. According to the designation, thirteen broad categories of participants have been detected during the conduct of this study. A maximum of 61% of participants were technicians. The second maximum 8.3% of participants were operators. Thirteen categories of work sections have been counted among the LAB factories. More than one-fourth of the participants were from the assembly section. The second maximum, 22.2% of participants were from the plate preparation section. To measure the education status, half of the participants had high school level education. There was evidence that the maximum LAB-producing worker’s education was up to class ten secondary level [ [8] [15] More than half of the participants in our study worked in workplaces with uncomfortable room temperatures. These workplaces with high room temperatures showed evidence of occupational heat stress and could impair kidney health [ 16 2 4 [17] [18] 15 19 20 Among the nineteen lead exposure symptoms, only nine (insomnia, abdominal pain, joint pain, memory loss, LBP, ESP, physical weakness, hypertension) symptoms were prominent among the participants. This study also revealed that 9.7% of the participants had minor injuries or accidents. Among all the work sections, assembling section was the most significantly vulnerable section for lead exposure where we found all prominent symptoms of lead exposure among the participants. In the assembling section, 15.3% of participants had physical weakness during conducting this surveillance. The formation section was the safest section of the factory where nobody had the nine topmost symptoms of lead exposure. The plate preparation section was the second most dangerous section of the battery-producing factory. Chemical smell and lead exposure had a positive association with clinical cardiovascular diseases like hypertension [ [16] [21] 2 4 22 [15] [17] 6 23 The importance of our result was to identify work patterns that were harmful to the LAB workers as well as identification of workplace environments that had several adverse impacts on health. Among twenty-one health-related questions a total nineteen lead exposure-related questions have been asked and remaining two questions were enquired regarding the identification of workplace accident or injury. We also identified the vulnerable section of the LAB-producing factory. This research focuses on the relationship between presence of exposure to certain adverse conditions and chemical and physical agents and related potential adverse health outcomes in LAB factory workplaces and among workers with low socio-economic status and education. Although this work is currently in its preliminary stages and lacks sufficient quantitative data, it is the first of its kind to be conducted by occupational health researchers in Bangladesh. As a result, it has significant value for the field of occupational health and safety research in the country. We recognize the study’s limitations and acknowledge that future researchers will need to collect additional health outcomes’ data and conduct exposure assessment with new generation environmental monitoring devices. Despite the limited data currently available, this type of research is incredibly valuable in improving occupational health and safety in Bangladesh, particularly for the LAB-related industrial sector. Both work patterns and workplace environments had impact on the health of workers. Proper ventilation can reduce the air lead level to keep exposure levels within the occupational exposure limits [ 24 25 26 While this study provides valuable insights into the occupational hazards faced by workers in LAB factories in Bangladesh, some limitations should be acknowledged. The cross-sectional design restricted our ability to establish causality between exposures and health outcomes. All the answers of the participants were based only on their assumptions or feelings, but we did not test their answers in terms of work patterns, workplace environment, and their health issues. Additionally, relying on self-reported data for health symptoms might introduce recall bias. Likewise, to identify work patterns and workplace environmental impact on the health of the participants, some close-end questions did not expose the participants’ knowledge properly because participants may choose their answer just under the assumption. The use of objective health assessments could improve the accuracy of our findings in future research. In conclusion, this manuscript highlights the significant occupational hazards faced by workers in LAB factories in Bangladesh and emphasizes the urgent need for improved workplace safety measures. The comprehensive assessment conducted in this study revealed that workers in these factories are exposed to excess heat, high noise levels, and hazardous chemicals, leading to potential health impacts on their well-being. Our preliminary research can provide valuable insights to policymakers, industry stakeholders, and health professionals on how to reduce hazards in LAB factories and minimize related health risks for workers. For example, the NOSHRTI (National Occupational Safety and Health Research and Training Institute) and the DIFE (Department for Inspections of Factories and Establishments) of Bangladesh can collaborate to support the LAB factory workers to ensure a decent workplace and sound occupational health. The NOSHTRI can identify the potential hazards and lead exposure-related health risks in this industry sector and provide recommendations and reports accordingly. Conversely, the DIFE is responsible for enforcing labor laws related to occupational health and safety to ensure that factories comply with green LAB regulations. Therefore, the DIFE can train managers in violated LAB factories on occupational health and safety based on the data they obtain from the NOSHTRI in Bangladesh.
